questions.text: Nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. C fibres

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve fibre least susceptible to local anaesthetic is type C. Local anaesthetics work by blocking sodium channels, which prevents the initiation and propagation of action potentials in nerves. The effectiveness of local anaesthetics depends on the diameter and myelination of the nerve fibres.

 

Type C fibres are unmyelinated and have the smallest diameter, making them the least susceptible to local anaesthetics. This means they require a higher concentration of the anaesthetic to achieve the same level of blockade as larger, myelinated fibres.

 

The order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics is:

 

B > A-d > A-g > A-b > A-a > C

 

  • Nerve fibres most susceptible to local anesthetic: B fibres

  • Nerve fibres most resistant to local anesthetic: C fibres

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-delta: These are myelinated fibres with a small diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to C fibres but less susceptible than larger, myelinated fibres like A-beta and A-alpha.

 

Option B. A-gamma: These are myelinated fibres with a moderate diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta fibres but less susceptible than A-beta and A-alpha fibres.

 

Option C. A-beta: These are myelinated fibres with a larger diameter, making them more susceptible to local anaesthetics compared to A-delta and A-gamma fibres.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Type C nerve fibres are the least susceptible to local anaesthetics due to their small diameter and lack of myelination.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1416-1417

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefazolin

 

The drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery is Cefazolin, a first-generation cephalosporin. This class of antibiotics is preferred due to their efficacy against the most frequently encountered pathogenic organisms causing surgical site infections in cardiac surgeries.

 

  • Antimicrobial prophylaxis: Administered to cover the most frequently encountered pathogenic organisms causing surgical site infections.
  • Timing: The first dose should be given within 60 minutes before skin incision for an optimal duration of 24 hours but should not exceed 48 hours.
  • Special cases: In MRSA-positive cases, Vancomycin is indicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: Not typically used for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery as it does not cover the range of organisms most commonly associated with surgical site infections in this context.

 

Option B. Erythromycin: Not the preferred choice for surgical prophylaxis in cardiac surgery due to its spectrum of activity and potential side effects.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: While it has a broad spectrum of activity, it is not the standard choice for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in cardiac surgery is Cefazolin, administered within 60 minutes before incision to prevent surgical site infections.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

 

The LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device. Second-generation devices are designed to be safer than first-generation devices, offering a higher pressure pharyngeal seal and a reduced risk of aspiration. These devices often have two tubes: one for ventilation (airway tube) and another for draining gastric secretions (gastric tube). The LMA Proseal, specifically, features these characteristics, making it a second-generation device.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA Fastrach: LMA Fastrach, also known as the intubating LMA, is not categorized as either a first or second-generation device. It is classified as a special LMA due to its unique design, which facilitates difficult intubations.

 

 

Option B. LMA Flexible: The LMA Flexible is a variant of the LMA Classic, which is a first-generation device. It has a flexible airway tube but lacks the features of second-generation devices, such as a high-pressure pharyngeal seal and an additional tube for gastric drainage.

 

 

Option D. Ambu LMA: The Ambu LMA does not have the dual-tube system that characterizes second-generation devices.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

questions.text: A patient who was on a ventilator for one week suddenly gets agitated and self-extubates himself. What is the next step of management? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

 

  • This is the most logical and safest immediate action. By observing the patient's spontaneous breathing, clinicians can gauge whether the patient is in distress or if they're maintaining their airway and oxygenating adequately. Self-extubation doesn't automatically necessitate re-intubation. If the patient is breathing well and does not desaturate, self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. This can be confirmed by doing an arterial blood gas of the patient and checking his PaO2/FiO2 ratio and also watching for spontaneous breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Re-intubate: Simply re-intubating without assessment can be a precipitous action. It might be unnecessary if the patient can maintain their airway and oxygenation without assistance. Additionally, re-intubation has its own set of risks, including injury to the airway, so it's not a decision to be taken lightly.

 

Option B. Oxygenate and re-intubate: While it's always important to ensure a patient is well-oxygenated, especially if there's potential for re-intubation, the decision to re-intubate should be based on the patient's clinical status and not solely on the fact that they've self-extubated.

 

Option C. Start CPR: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is initiated in situations of cardiac arrest. There's no indication in the scenario that the patient's heart has stopped. Starting CPR without evidence of cardiac arrest can cause harm, including broken ribs and internal injury.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Self-extubation requires careful assessment to determine if re-intubation is necessary. Observing the patient's spontaneous breathing and oxygenation status is crucial before making the decision to re-intubate.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

  • To monitor adequacy of neuromuscular blockade ulnar nerve is preferred.
  • It is monitored using a Train of Four monitor/peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle is seen on electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is frequently used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade during and after anesthesia.
  • It is typically monitored using a device known as a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • The ulnar nerve is accessible and provides a reliable location for monitoring. Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle (a muscle in the thumb) is commonly observed when electrical stimulation is applied to the ulnar nerve.
  • This twitch response is used to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median nerve: While the median nerve can be used for neuromuscular monitoring, the ulnar nerve is more commonly preferred because of its accessibility and ease of stimulation. The adductor pollicis muscle twitch response is typically more reliable for assessing neuromuscular blockade compared to other muscles.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: The radial nerve can also be used for neuromuscular monitoring, but it is not as commonly chosen as the ulnar nerve. Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve offers a more reliable and standard location for monitoring.

 

Option D. Metacarpal nerve: There is no specific nerve called the "metacarpal nerve" commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, typically assessed using a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.

questions.text: What is the correct ratio of chest compressions to breaths when a lone rescuer is performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. 30:2

 

Explanation:


According to the American Heart Association (AHA) 2015 guidelines, the recommended ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths during CPR for all adults, whether performed by a single rescuer or two rescuers, is 30:2. This means the rescuer should deliver 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths. This ratio ensures adequate circulation and oxygenation during resuscitation efforts.

 

Other options:


Option A. 10:1: This ratio is not recommended for any age group or CPR scenario.


Option B. 15:1: This ratio is incorrect; however, a 15:2 ratio is used in some pediatric cases with two rescuers.


Option C. 30:1: This ratio is incorrect; the correct ratio is 30:2.

 

Educational Objective:


When performing CPR, the correct ratio of chest compressions to breaths for a lone rescuer is 30:2, ensuring effective circulation and oxygenation

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his ETCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

 

Explanation:

 

Venous Air Embolism:

 

  • Definition: It refers to the entry of air into the venous system, which can then travel to the heart and block the pulmonary circulation.
  • Presentation: A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and potential cardiac arrhythmias. A "mill wheel" murmur might be heard on auscultation.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The sudden drop in ETCO2, combined with hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia following manipulation of the internal jugular vein during surgery in a head-up position, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

There are four important events here:

  1. Bleeding from the internal jugular vein (severed vein which can entrap air)
  2. A drastic fall in ETCO2
  3. Hypotension
  4. Neck surgery – requires head-up position which reduces blood pressure in neck veins

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sympathetic Overactivity:

  • Definition: It refers to excessive stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Presentation: It typically manifests as hypertension (raised blood pressure) and tachycardia (increased heart rate).
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The patient developed hypotension, not hypertension, so this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Vagal Stimulation:

  • Definition: Activation of the vagus nerve, one of the cranial nerves, which plays a role in controlling the heart, lungs, and digestive tract.
  • Presentation: Vagal stimulation can cause bradycardia (slowed heart rate) and hypotension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: While vagal stimulation can explain the hypotension and arrhythmia, it does not account for the drastic drop in ETCO2.

 

Option D. Carotid Body Stimulation:

  • Definition: The carotid body is a small cluster of chemoreceptors located at the bifurcation of the carotid artery. It monitors changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • Presentation: Stimulation can cause changes in heart rate and blood pressure, but it typically results in hypertension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: Given that the patient is hypotensive, this option is less likely.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias during surgery, especially involving the internal jugular vein and head-up positioning, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1878-1880

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the  following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.

 

Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions 

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetic causes least myocardial depression and maximum hemodynamic stability? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Etomidate

 

  • Among the options given, Etomidate is unique in that it causes minimal cardiovascular depression.
  • This makes it particularly useful in patients with compromised cardiac function or hemodynamic instability
  • Etomidate is an imidazoline derivative used for IV anaesthesia induction, and it offers several advantages:
    • Low risk of myocardial depression
    • Hemodynamic stability on bolus injection

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in blood pressure. It also produces vasodilation which can further lower blood pressure.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone can cause myocardial depression, leading to a decrease in cardiac output and blood pressure. It also has a vasodilatory effect which can further compromise hemodynamics.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Unlike most other anesthetics, Ketamine typically has a stimulatory effect on the cardiovascular system. It often increases heart rate and blood pressure due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects. However, in patients with depleted catecholamines or in certain pathological conditions, it might not exhibit this stimulatory effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol and Thiopentone are known to cause myocardial depression, Etomidate is recognized for its minimal cardiovascular depression, and Ketamine typically stimulates the cardiovascular system, but with certain exceptions.

questions.text: Which of the following local  anaesthetic causes hypertension?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

Cocaine: An ester local anesthetic that is also a powerful central nervous system stimulant. One of the well-known cardiovascular effects of cocaine is hypertension, due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: is an amide local anesthetic that is used to produce numbness during procedures and for treating various types of pain. It can cause side effects such as dizziness and low blood pressure but is not known for causing hypertension.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: An amide local anesthetic known for its potent and long-lasting numbing effect. It can cause cardiovascular complications, but like lignocaine, it is more associated with cardiac toxicity rather than hypertension.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Another amide local anesthetic, similar to lignocaine, and not commonly associated with causing hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is the local anesthetic known to cause hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acute myocardial infarction

 

Explanation:

 

Acute myocardial infarction: Morphine is often used in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) to relieve pain and anxiety. It also has the beneficial effect of reducing preload and afterload on the heart, which can decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This makes it beneficial in the management of AMI. It's not a contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can induce histamine release, which may lead to bronchospasm. In patients with bronchial asthma, this bronchospasm can exacerbate respiratory difficulties, making morphine potentially dangerous for these patients.

 

Option B. Renal failure: Morphine is metabolized in the liver and its metabolites, especially morphine-6-glucuronide, are excreted by the kidneys. In the case of renal failure, these active metabolites can accumulate, leading to prolonged and potentially toxic effects.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Morphine has a depressive effect on the respiratory center in the brain, leading to respiratory depression. In patients with emphysema, a condition already characterized by compromised respiratory function, morphine can exacerbate respiratory difficulties and decrease the drive to breathe.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Morphine is beneficial and not contraindicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as it helps to relieve pain, reduce anxiety, and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text:
Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. 22G cannula

  2. 24G IV cannula

  3. 5-mL syringe

  4. Adhesive tape

  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

 

Explanation:

 

2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.

3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.

4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.

5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.

 

Other Option:

 

1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is undergoing a minor surgical procedure under sedation with spontaneous ventilation. The anesthesiologist needs to select the most appropriate breathing circuit to ensure efficient gas exchange and minimal work of breathing. The goal is to maintain spontaneous respiration with optimal support throughout the procedure. Which of the following anesthesia circuits is most effective for spontaneous breathing in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Mapleson A

 

 

Explanation:

 

Mapleson A, also known as Magill’s circuit, is the most effective anesthesia breathing circuit for spontaneous breathing in adults. It is designed to minimize the work of breathing and efficiently eliminate carbon dioxide during spontaneous respiration. In the Mapleson classification, the circuits are tailored for specific purposes: Mapleson A is optimal for spontaneous breathing because the APL valve is located at the patient’s end, facilitating efficient exhalation of expired gases and fresh gas flow, which reduces the risk of rebreathing. For controlled ventilation, Mapleson D (Bain’s circuit) is preferred due to its distal APL valve design that supports positive pressure ventilation. Meanwhile, Mapleson F is the most effective for pediatric patients, as it provides low resistance and minimal dead space suitable for smaller tidal volumes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mapleson F: Mapleson F, or Jackson Rees’ modification, is primarily used in pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space. It is less suitable for adults because it does not adequately prevent rebreathing with larger tidal volumes, making it less effective for spontaneous breathing in this patient population.

 

Option B. Mapleson E: Mapleson E is a non-rebreathing circuit without a reservoir bag or APL valve, primarily used in pediatric patients. It lacks the necessary control over airway pressures, making it inefficient for spontaneous breathing in adults.

 

Option D. Mapleson C: Mapleson C has a similar setup to Mapleson A but lacks the corrugation in its breathing tube, resulting in increased resistance and less effective carbon dioxide elimination. This design makes it less suitable for spontaneous breathing compared to Mapleson A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For adults, Mapleson A (Magill’s circuit) is the most effective circuit for spontaneous breathing, while Mapleson D (Bain’s circuit) is best for controlled ventilation. For pediatric patients, Mapleson F provides optimal performance due to its low resistance and minimal dead space. Understanding the specific applications of these circuits ensures proper ventilation support tailored to the patient's needs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2 concentration

 

Methods to confirm endotracheal intubation:

  • X-ray chest
  • Auscultation
  • End-tidal CO2 concentration
  • Chest rise

 

This is considered the best method to confirm ETT placement in real-time. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the exhaled breath. When the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea, it will produce a waveform with a consistent and relatively high end-tidal CO2 concentration. In contrast, if the ETT is in the esophagus or there is an airway obstruction, the end-tidal CO2 concentration will be lower or absent, providing immediate feedback to the anesthesiologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray chest: While a chest X-ray can confirm the placement of the ETT, it is not a practical or immediate method for confirming tube placement during intubation. X-rays are typically used for confirmation after intubation.

 

Option B. Auscultation: Auscultation involves listening to breath sounds over the chest and epigastrium to assess tube placement. While it can be a useful method, it may not always be reliable, especially in noisy clinical environments, and it may not detect esophageal intubation or partial airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Observing chest rise can be helpful, but it is not as reliable as capnography. In some cases, chest rise may be present even if the ETT is incorrectly placed in the esophagus, especially in cases of esophageal intubation with positive-pressure ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for confirming ETT placement is indeed the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.
  • It provides real-time feedback and is considered a more reliable method compared to other options, ensuring that the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea and the patient is being ventilated effectively.

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high-flow nasal cannula? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases need of intubation

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: High-flow nasal cannula allows for the delivery of oxygen at much higher flow rates than standard nasal cannulae. This higher flow rate can flush out the nasopharyngeal dead space, leading to a more consistent fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and improving alveolar ventilation.

 

Option C. Heating and humidification: One of the distinct features of HFNC systems is that they deliver oxygen that's both heated and humidified. This enhances comfort, reduces the risk of mucosal drying and injury, and can help improve mucociliary clearance.

 

Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): PEEP refers to the maintenance of a positive pressure in the airways at the end of expiration, which can prevent alveolar collapse. The high flow rate from HFNC can generate a degree of PEEP, especially with the mouth closed. This can help recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation in certain patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.

questions.text: What is the most common cause for hospital admission after day care surgery? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Postoperative nausea and vomiting

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge from the hospital post day care surgery is Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). PONV is a frequent complication following surgery and anesthesia, significantly impacting patient comfort and recovery, and often leading to extended hospital stays or readmissions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory distress: While it is a serious concern, it is not as commonly the cause for hospital admission after day care surgery as PONV.

 

Option B. Post-surgical pain: Although post-surgical pain is a common issue, it is generally managed effectively with analgesics and is less frequently the cause for hospital admission compared to PONV.

 

Option D. Bleeding: Postoperative bleeding can be a complication but is less common as a cause for hospital admission after day care surgery compared to PONV.

 

Risk factors for PONV:

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge after day care surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2603

choices.text: Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen
Radial artery is the preferred site

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ICU. While taking a blood sample for ABG, which of the following steps would you not do? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

 

Explanation:

 

Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood: Traditionally, to prevent blood from clotting inside the syringe when obtaining an ABG, a small amount of heparin was added to the syringe. However, in contemporary practice, syringes used for ABG are pre-heparinized, which means they already contain a coating of dry heparin that will mix with the blood sample and prevent clotting. Adding additional heparin to such a syringe is unnecessary and can dilute the sample, potentially altering the results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder: This statement is accurate. A patient can have a mixed acid-base disorder where two primary disorders (e.g., metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis) coexist and "cancel" each other out, leading to a seemingly "normal" pH. However, when the components of the arterial blood gas (ABG) like PaCO2 and HCO3- are evaluated, abnormalities can be detected.

 

Option C. If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen: The modified Allen's test is a simple way to evaluate the collateral blood flow to the hand via the ulnar artery. Before taking a sample or placing an arterial line in the radial artery, it's a recommended step to ensure that if the radial artery becomes occluded, the hand will still receive adequate blood flow. If the test is negative (indicative of inadequate collateral flow), it's safer to choose an alternate site for arterial puncture.

 

Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site: The radial artery is commonly chosen for ABG sampling and arterial line placement due to its accessibility, the presence of collateral blood flow (via the ulnar artery), and its relatively superficial location which makes puncture technically easier. Furthermore, complications like hematoma or injury are less problematic at this location when compared to other potential sites, such as the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Adding extra heparin to pre-heparinized ABG syringes is unnecessary and can alter the blood sample.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive investigations provides the most accurate prognostic information with respect to predicting risks of perioperative cardiac complications? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dobutamine stress echocardiography

 

  • This is an echocardiogram that is performed while the heart is under the stress of increased workload. If a patient cannot exercise, a drug called dobutamine is administered to simulate the effects of exercise on the heart.
  • The test helps identify areas of the heart that may not be receiving enough blood due to blockages in the coronary arteries. A significant change in the motion of the heart wall during the test is a strong predictor of perioperative cardiac complications, making this test highly valuable in the mentioned context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exercise ECG testing: Exercise ECG testing, also known as exercise stress testing or treadmill testing, involves the patient exercising on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while their heart rate, blood pressure, and electrocardiogram (ECG) are monitored. The purpose is to determine how the heart responds to the stress of exercise. Abnormal changes in the ECG during or after exercise may suggest coronary artery disease (CAD). While this test can indicate the presence of CAD, it does not specifically predict perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option C. Myocardial perfusion scintigraphy: Also known as a nuclear stress test, this investigation involves injecting a small amount of radioactive substance into the patient and using a special camera to visualize how blood flows through the heart muscle, both at rest and during stress (either exercise or with a medication). This test can identify areas of the heart that aren't getting enough blood, indicative of CAD. While it can detect and evaluate the severity of CAD, it's less specific than dobutamine stress echocardiography in predicting perioperative cardiac complications.

 

Option D. Coronary angiography: This is a procedure in which a contrast dye is injected into the coronary arteries, and X-rays are taken to visualize the flow of blood through these arteries. It is used to directly visualize blockages in the coronary arteries. As the "gold standard" for diagnosing CAD, coronary angiography can provide detailed information about the location and severity of blockages. However, it's an invasive procedure, involving threading a catheter through the blood vessels to the heart, and carries risks such as bleeding, allergic reactions, or kidney damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dobutamine stress echocardiography is the most accurate non-invasive investigation for predicting perioperative cardiac complications due to its ability to simulate exercise and identify areas of the heart with reduced blood flow.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 935

questions.text: The structure marked with the black arrow in the given picture arises from the ……… (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

This is a coronal section of the brain and the marked structure is the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mammillary body of the hypothalamus.

 

Hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe of the brain.

 

The hippocampus is critical for the formation and retrieval of memories, particularly episodic memories. It's also involved in spatial navigation. Damage or atrophy of the hippocampus can result in difficulties forming new memories. Conditions like Alzheimer's disease often exhibit significant hippocampal atrophy.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Mamillary body: Part of the diencephalon, present at the base of the brain, posterior to the pituitary gland.

 

  • The mammillary bodies are primarily associated with memory processing. They receive projections from the hippocampus via the fornix and send projections to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. They're particularly involved in the recall of past memories and are thought to play a role in spatial memory. Damage to the mammillary bodies, often due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, can lead to memory deficits.

 

Option C. Thalamus: Positioned centrally in the brain, the thalamus is a large mass of gray matter deep within the brain. It is part of the diencephalon.

 

  • Often referred to as the "relay station" of the brain, the thalamus receives sensory and motor signals and relays them to the cerebral cortex. It's involved in consciousness, sleep, and alertness. Thalamic strokes or lesions can lead to sensory deficits, altered consciousness, and movement disorders.

 

Option D. Amygdala: Located in the anterior portion of the temporal lobe, deep within the brain.

 

  • The amygdala plays a pivotal role in processing emotions, particularly fear and pleasure. It helps determine which memories are stored and where they are stored based on emotional significance. Dysfunction of the amygdala can lead to various emotional and behavioral abnormalities. It's also implicated in conditions such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronal Section of Brain

choices.text: Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after collapsing suddenly at a clinic where he had undergone a minor procedure under local anesthesia. Upon arrival, he is unresponsive with a blood pressure of 70/40 mm Hg and a heart rate of 130 beats per minute. During the resuscitation process, he develops cardiac arrhythmias and seizures. His condition rapidly deteriorates despite initial supportive measures. A 20% Intralipid injection is administered as part of the resuscitation efforts, leading to gradual stabilization of his symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST)

 

Explanation:


Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) occurs when local anesthetics are inadvertently administered into the bloodstream or absorbed systemically at toxic levels. This can lead to central nervous system symptoms like seizures and cardiovascular collapse, including severe hypotension and arrhythmias. Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically in LAST as a rescue therapy. It acts as a lipid sink, binding the anesthetic and reducing its concentration in the plasma, thereby reversing the toxic effects and stabilizing the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Anaphylactic shock: Typically presents with hypotension, bronchospasm, and rash after allergen exposure and is treated primarily with epinephrine, not Intralipid.

 

Option B) Septic shock: Associated with severe infection, systemic inflammatory response, and is treated with fluids, antibiotics, and vasopressors, not lipid emulsions.

 

Option D) Myocardial infarction: Characterized by chest pain, ECG changes, and elevated cardiac enzymes, managed with antiplatelets, anticoagulants, and reperfusion strategies, not with Intralipid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:


Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by neurological and cardiovascular manifestations due to excessive local anesthetic absorption. 20% Intralipid therapy is a key treatment modality for LAST, acting as a lipid sink to reduce circulating levels of the anesthetic and reverse toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the organism and the staining method used in the provided image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nocardia acid fast stain

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows filamentous bacteria with partial acid-fastness, characteristic of Nocardia species stained using an acid-fast technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus gram stain: Shows gram-positive cocci, not filamentous bacteria.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus india ink: Would reveal spherical yeast forms with a clear halo.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis PAS stain: Typically shows spherules rather than filamentous structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are identified using an acid-fast stain, which highlights their filamentous and partially acid-fast nature.

choices.text: Tzanck cells
Pund cells

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tzanck cells

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of genital herpes.

 

Tzanck cells – multinucleate giant cells seen on Tzanck smear in herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Herpetic lesions usually begin as clusters of small bumps, then blisters, followed by open sores or ulcers. Lesions coalesce and usually heal over several weeks at various rates. Local pain is a prominent and common complaint. Patients with genital herpes may also complain of pain in the groin area secondary to local adenopathy. Women often present with complaints of genital swelling, discharge, and dysuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pund cells: Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. Seen in granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) which is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Donovanosis lesions usually start as a painless papule or subcutaneous nodule. The lesions develop the classic “beefy-red” appearance due to their high vascularity. The initial lesion takes on an ulcerative morphology after minor trauma. There is usually no regional lymphadenopathy. Developing subcutaneous granulomas known as pseudo buboes is possible.

 

 

Option C. Henderson-Patterson bodies: intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies, or Henderson-Paterson bodies) are seen in molluscum contagiosum. Lesions are painless, discrete, nontender, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules (bumps, dimples) that show a central umbilication.

 

 

Option D. Guarnieri bodies: B-type inclusions, formerly known as Guarnieri bodies are cellular features found upon microscopic inspection of epithelial cells of individuals suspected of having poxvirus or vaccinia virus.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of Tzanck cells, which are multinucleated giant cells, is indicative of herpes simplex virus infection. This is the most likely microscopic finding in a patient with painful genital lesions consistent with genital herpes.

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sequestered in body tissues

 

  • A Vd (volume of distribution) of 6 L/kg means approx. 420 L (6 x 70) in a 70 Kg person. It is much higher than blood volume of 5L.
  • A high Vd suggests that the drug is extensively distributed beyond the blood and into the tissues. This often implies that the drug has a high affinity for tissues, effectively getting "sequestered" or stored there.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Highly bound to plasma proteins: A drug that is highly bound to plasma proteins would typically have a lower Vd because it is mostly confined to the bloodstream. Plasma protein binding keeps the drug within the vascular space, preventing its distribution into tissues.

 

Option B. Confined to vascular compartment: A low Vd would suggest that the drug is primarily in the vascular compartment, including plasma and blood cells. A high Vd of 6L/kg indicates the opposite, suggesting that the drug is widely distributed in tissues rather than confined to the vascular compartment.

 

Therefore, a high Vd suggests that the drug is stored or sequestered in various body tissues, making option C the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high volume of distribution (Vd) suggests that the drug is widely distributed throughout the body and sequestered in various tissues, rather than being confined to the bloodstream or vascular compartment.

questions.text: Which vitamin can be synthesized internally by humans? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

Niacin, unlike most vitamins, can be synthesized endogenously from the amino acid tryptophan. This synthesis involves a complex biochemical pathway that converts tryptophan to nicotinic acid and nicotinamide, the active forms of niacin. These forms serve crucial roles in oxidation-reduction reactions as components of the coenzymes NAD and NADP. Niacin deficiency can lead to pellagra, a condition characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (skin inflammation), diarrhea, and dementia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Pantothenic Acid: This vitamin is essential and must be consumed through the diet as it cannot be synthesized by the body.
  • Option C. Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12): Humans cannot synthesize Vitamin B12; it must be ingested, with sources primarily being animal-based foods.
  • Option D. Folic Acid: This is another essential vitamin that must be obtained from dietary sources, especially green leafy vegetables.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin can be synthesized in the human body from tryptophan, making it unique among vitamins.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases trabecular outflow?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Netarsudil

 

Netarsudil is used in the treatment of glaucoma, it is a Rho-kinase inhibitor that acts by increasing the trabecular outflow. The other drugs that act by increasing the trabecular outflow are the miotic drugs like Pilocarpine, Physostigmine and Ecothiophate.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Timolol: Is a non-selective Beta blocker which is used in treatment of glaucoma. It acts by reducing the aqueous formation.

 

Option C. Brimonidine: Is a topical alpha-receptor agonist. It acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and reduces the aqueous formation

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor which reduces aqueous formation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Netarsudil is effective in treating glaucoma by increasing trabecular outflow. This mechanism distinguishes it from other drugs like Timolol, Brimonidine, and Acetazolamide, which primarily reduce aqueous humor production or increase uveoscleral outflow.

choices.text: 3 iron and folic acid (IFA) tablets, taken OD
IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets
2 iron and folic acid tablets OD + IV iron sucrose

questions.text: A pregnant woman presenting at less than 34 weeks of gestation displays signs of mild to moderate anemia. Under the "Anemia Mukh Bharat" initiative, which therapeutic approach would be the most appropriate? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets

 

The best treatment among the given options is IV iron sucrose for non-compliance with oral tablets.

 

Severity of Anemia according to Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign,

 

  • Mild – 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate – 7-9 g%
  • Severe – <7 g %

 

Testing and treating Mild and Moderate Anemia:

 

  • If mild anemia OR moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron and folic acid
  • If patient presents late in pregnancy or is unable to tolerate oral iron: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe anemia:

 

  • Hb < 7g%: Parenteral iron – IV Iron sucrose or Ferric carboxymaltose (FeCM).
  • If patient presents late in the third trimester with severe anemia or Hb is less than 5 g%: ADMIT

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat (2018)

 

Aim: Reduce anemia by 3% per year

 

6 x 6 x 6 strategy

questions.text:
A 40-year-old smoker who is a known case of hypertension was on enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He had an episode of hemoptysis and on evaluation, he was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma with brain metastasis. His lab values were Na-124mg/dL, creatinine - 2.8mg%, blood sugar 112mg/dL, blood urea - 24mg/dL, serum osmolality 255mosm, urine osmolality - 110 mosm, 24-hour urinary sodium - 110 and BP - 150/90 mmHg.

 

Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of the low sodium values in him? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SIADH

 

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) is the most probable diagnosis in this patient. The diagnostic criteria and the patient's clinical presentation support this conclusion:

 

 

Additionally, lung cancer (specifically bronchogenic carcinoma) can often cause SIADH, either through ectopic production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or related paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diuretic induced hyponatremia: Incorrect because the pattern of serum and urine osmolality does not align solely with diuretic use; the high urine sodium and euvolemia are more indicative of SIADH.

 

Option C. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Incorrect as this condition typically presents with hypovolemia and low blood pressure due to significant sodium and fluid loss, which is not evident in this patient who maintains a normal blood pressure.

 

Option D. Pseudohyponatremia: Incorrect because the reduced serum osmolality directly indicates true hyponatremia, not a distortion caused by high levels of lipids or proteins in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIADH can be associated with malignancies like lung cancer, presenting with hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and inappropriately concentrated urine despite the presence of low plasma osmolality. This clinical scenario should prompt consideration of SIADH, particularly in patients with known malignancies and typical lab findings.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance, and hand and foot enlargement. What is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pegvisomant

 

The patient's symptoms suggest acromegaly, a condition characterized by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma. Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It blocks the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, leading to decreased levels of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which is responsible for the acromegaly symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue, which can be used in the treatment of acromegaly. It works by inhibiting the release of growth hormone from the pituitary gland. However, it is not a growth hormone receptor antagonist; instead, it reduces GH secretion.

 

Option C. Cabergoline: Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist primarily used in the treatment of prolactinomas, another type of pituitary adenoma. It is not typically used as a first-line treatment for acromegaly and does not act as a growth hormone receptor antagonist.

 

Option D. Olcegepant: Olcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist used in the research for migraine treatment. It is not used in the treatment of acromegaly or related to growth hormone activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly by blocking the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, thereby reducing the symptoms associated with elevated growth hormone levels.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity decreases in fasting? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphofructokinase 1

 

Phosphofructokinase 1 (PFK-1) is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis that catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. Its activity is increased in the fed state and decreased during fasting. During fasting, the body's metabolic state shifts to prioritize gluconeogenesis and fatty acid oxidation, leading to a decrease in glycolytic enzyme activities, including PFK-1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hormone-sensitive lipase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Mobilizes fatty acids from adipose tissue by breaking down triglycerides.

 

Option B. Glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Breaks down glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate in the liver and muscles, providing glucose during fasting.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Activity: Increases during fasting.
  • Function: Catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a key step in gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: What concentration of tetanus antitoxin in the blood is considered clinically protective against tetanus? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) >0.01 IU/ml

 

  • Specific antibody concentrations greater than 0.01 IU/mL were considered protective against tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aim of active Immunisation with TT:

 

  • Vaccinate the entire community
  • Ensure protective level of antitoxin ~ 0.01 IU/mL serum throughout life

questions.text: What method is most effective for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence within a given area over time? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Line graph

 

Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot the changes in the incidence of a disease in a given area over time (TREND of any event).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histogram: Is graphical presentation for ‘continuous quantitative data’

 

  • Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

 

Option C. Ogive:  Is graph of cumulative relative frequency distribution

 

 

Option D. Stem and leaf plot:  Represents quantitative data in graphical format which helps us visualize the shape of distribution. We are able to represent frequencies for different classes of values.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Line graphs are the most effective method for visually representing the fluctuations in disease occurrence over time, making them ideal for identifying and analyzing trends in epidemiological data.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

 

The National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey conducted from 2015 to 2019 revealed that untreated cataract is the leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment (MSVI). MSVI is characterized by a presenting visual acuity of <6/18 to 3/60 in the better eye despite available correction. Visual impairment and blindness are frequently observed in individuals who are 50 years old and above.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Refractive errors are the leading cause of MSVI in patients aged 49 years and below.

 

Options C and Option D: Glaucoma and diabetic retinopathy account for a very low number of visual impairment cases in patients aged 50 years and above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks. What is the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG to see cervical length

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has several risk factors for preterm labor, including a history of previous preterm births and cervical conization. The appropriate next step in management is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound (USG) to measure the cervical length at 11-14 weeks of gestation.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cervical length measurement: If the cervix is found to be short (less than 2.5 cm), with or without funneling of the internal os, cervical cerclage may be indicated.
  • Progesterone supplementation: If the cervical length is normal, the patient should be started on progesterone and serial cervical length measurements should be continued.
  • Cervical cerclage: This is a procedure where a suture is placed around the cervix to prevent or delay preterm birth. It can be done via the vaginal route using techniques like McDonald’s or Shirodkar's.
  • Abdominal cerclage: This is considered for patients with a prior failed vaginal cerclage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical Cerclage: While cerclage may be necessary, it should be based on the findings of cervical length measurement. Immediate cerclage without assessment is not recommended.

 

Option C. Complete Bed rest: Bed rest alone is not an effective strategy for preventing preterm labor and is not indicated without further assessment.

 

Option D. Abdominal cerclage: This is reserved for patients with a history of failed vaginal cerclage and is not the first-line approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with risk factors for preterm labor, including a history of cervical conization and previous preterm births, the next step is to perform a transvaginal ultrasound to measure cervical length at 11-14 weeks of gestation. Based on the findings, appropriate interventions, such as cervical cerclage or progesterone supplementation, can be considered.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg2094

questions.text: Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta from the fetus through? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Umbilical artery

 

Explanation:

 

Fetal circulation:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Umbilical vein: Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, not deoxygenated blood.

 

Option C. Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta in fetal circulation, bypassing the lungs. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC, allowing oxygenated blood to bypass the liver. It does not return deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deoxygenated blood exits the fetus through the umbilical arteries, which return it to the placenta.

 

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: RSI should be avoided in patients with a full stomach to prevent aspiration.
RSI involves preoxygenation and simultaneous administration of an induction agent and a paralytic agent.
Bag-mask ventilation is routinely performed between induction and paralysis to ensure oxygenation.
RSI is primarily indicated in cardiac arrest patients who require intubation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress due to worsening pulmonary edema. He is visibly struggling to breathe, with labored respirations and low oxygen saturation despite supplemental oxygen. The medical team decides to perform rapid sequence intubation (RSI) to secure his airway. Which of the following statements about RSI is correct?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) RSI involves preoxygenation and simultaneous administration of an induction agent and a paralytic agent.

 

Explanation:


Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is a technique used to secure the airway in patients who are at high risk of aspiration, such as those with acute respiratory distress, trauma, or other emergent conditions. RSI is particularly valuable because it minimizes the time between the loss of protective airway reflexes and the placement of the endotracheal tube, thereby reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Preoxygenation: This step involves administering 100% oxygen for 3-5 minutes to fill the patient’s lungs with oxygen, creating an oxygen reserve to minimize hypoxemia during the apneic period.

 

Simultaneous Administration of Medications: An induction agent (e.g., etomidate, propofol, ketamine) is given to induce unconsciousness, and a neuromuscular blocking agent (e.g., succinylcholine, rocuronium) is given to achieve paralysis. The simultaneous administration ensures rapid onset of unconsciousness and paralysis, facilitating quick and controlled intubation.

 

Avoidance of Bag-Mask Ventilation: Bag-mask ventilation is generally avoided between induction and intubation to prevent gastric insufflation and reduce the risk of aspiration, which is particularly critical in patients with a full stomach.

 

Intubation and Confirmation: The endotracheal tube is placed swiftly, and its position is confirmed using clinical assessment and tools like capnography.

 

Indications:

 

Patients at high risk of aspiration (e.g., with a full stomach, gastrointestinal bleeding).

Severe respiratory distress or failure where airway control is critical.

Trauma patients needing immediate airway protection.

 

Contraindications:

 

Situations where the patient is already in cardiac arrest; intubation is prioritized without the use of drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) RSI should be avoided in patients with a full stomach to prevent aspiration: This is incorrect because RSI is specifically designed for patients at risk of aspiration, including those with a full stomach, to quickly secure the airway and prevent gastric contents from entering the lungs.

Option C) Bag-mask ventilation is routinely performed between induction and paralysis to ensure oxygenation: This is incorrect as routine bag-mask ventilation is avoided during RSI to prevent increasing the risk of aspiration due to gastric insufflation.

 

Option D) RSI is primarily indicated in cardiac arrest patients who require intubation: This is incorrect because in cardiac arrest, securing the airway is done without delay and often without the need for induction agents or paralytics, as these patients are unresponsive.

 

Educational Objective:


Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is a critical procedure for securing the airway in patients at high risk of aspiration. The key components include preoxygenation and simultaneous administration of an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent, followed by immediate intubation without intermediate ventilation, ensuring rapid and safe airway control.

choices.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding the healing of leprosy if left untreated? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Among the given options, Indeterminate leprosy has more remission than tuberculoid is the most appropriate answer

 

The bacillus Mycobacterium leprae is the source of the chronic infectious granulomatous disease known as leprosy (Hansen's disease).

 

Clinically, leprosy can exhibit one or more of the following symptoms

 

  • Patches of hypopigmentation
  • Presence of thickened nerves, and
  • Partial or complete loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas (First sensory modality to be lost is Temperature (hot/cold differentiation).
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in nasal smears or the skin.

 

Leprosy symptoms vary depending on how an individual's immune system reacts to the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae. Spontaneous resolution can be seen in about 80–90% (NOT just 50% as given in Option B) of people after being exposed to bacteria.  The remaining patients get clinical leprosy. Indeterminate leprosy typically has hypopigmented, ill-defined lesions. 75 percent of those Indeterminate leprosy patients experience spontaneous remission.

 

Clinically, very few patients exhibit either lepromatous leprosy or tuberculoid leprosy. As a result, compared to patients with tuberculoid leprosy, more patients with indeterminate leprosy experience spontaneous remission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No spontaneous remission is seen: Incorrect. Spontaneous remission can occur in leprosy, particularly in the indeterminate and sometimes in the tuberculoid forms due to the individual's immune response.

 

Note - Even in the absence of specific treatment, a majority (80-90%) of patients tend to get cured spontaneously.

 

Option B. Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure. Incorrect. While many individuals may be exposed to Mycobacterium leprae and not develop full-blown leprosy due to a robust immune response, the assertion that half of the cases resolve spontaneously is not accurate. A higher percentage may never progress to clinical disease.

 

Option C. Spontaneous remission in children is variable when compared to adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spontaneous remission occurs even in the absence of specific treatment in majority (almost 80-90%) of the patients, but when compared to adults, in children spontaneous cure is very much variable.
  • If left untreated, Indeterminate leprosy has a higher rate of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 28.7

Parks textbook of preventive & social medicine 26th edition Pg 359

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease." This fungal infection occurs when the fungus, which lives in soil, plants, and decaying vegetation, enters the skin through small cuts or punctures. The infection usually starts as a small nodule at the site of entry and can spread along lymphatic channels, causing nodular lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus neoformans: This fungus is typically associated with systemic infections, particularly cryptococcal meningitis, in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV/AIDS. It is not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option B. Histoplasma capsulatum: This is a systemic mycotic agent that causes histoplasmosis, a respiratory infection that can disseminate in immunocompromised individuals. It is not a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Option D. Talaromyces marneffei: Formerly known as Penicillium marneffei, this fungus causes systemic mycoses, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those with HIV/AIDS. It is endemic in Southeast Asia and not classified as a subcutaneous fungal agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The term systemic mycoses is used here to refer to infections caused by organisms in the following genera: Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Histoplasma, and Cryptococcus.

questions.text: Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings:  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.
  • Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low
  • Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal. 
  • PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio
  • Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen

 

Educational Objective:

 

To correctly diagnose the underlying cause of secondary amenorrhea, it is essential to understand and interpret the hormonal profiles associated with different conditions:

 

  • Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency.
  • Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring.
  • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins.
  • Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg 380,

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. T4-T5

 

Explanation:

 

The cross-section shown in the image is at the level of T4-T5.

 

Ascending and Descending aorta are visible separately along with bifurcation of pulmonary trunk, this implies it is the section of T4-T5 level.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, Option B: In cross-sections at the levels of T1-T2 and T2-T3, only the small vascular openings of the branches arising from the arch of aorta would be visible.

 

Option C: In cross section of T3-T4 level  - section of arch of aorta along with branches of arch of aorta would be visible

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk along with separate ascending and descending aorta are clearing pointing towards T4-T5 level.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has malaise for 2 weeks. His investigations revealed an elevated creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. His blood tests also showed the presence of HBs antigen. A renal biopsy was performed which demonstrated spike and dome on special staining. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous glomerulopathy

 

The elderly patient is having a renal dysfunction. The presence of a ‘spike and dome’ pattern on special staining (silver staining) is suggestive of immune complex deposition. This is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy. The diagnosis isd also supported by the presence of HBs antigen as the hepatitis B infection is characteristically associated with development of membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children and does not show the spike and dome pattern on biopsy. No change on light microscopy; Electron microscopy shows podocyte effacement

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli, not associated with the spike and dome pattern.

 

Option D. Renal amyloidosis: Demonstrates amyloid deposits that can be identified with Congo red staining and apple-green birefringence under polarized light, not a spike and dome pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous glomerulopathy, associated with hepatitis B infection, presents with nephrotic syndrome and demonstrates a characteristic spike and dome pattern on renal biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Histology: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

questions.text: Which hormone is not responsible for intrauterine growth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Growth hormone

 

Explanation:


Growth hormone (GH) plays a crucial role in postnatal growth and development, but it is not significant during intrauterine (fetal) growth. During fetal development, the receptors for growth hormone are not sufficiently developed, which limits its ability to influence growth in utero. Instead, other hormones such as insulin, thyroxine, and insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) are critical for intrauterine growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin: This hormone is essential for fetal growth as it promotes the storage of glucose and fats, providing energy for developing tissues.

 

Option B. Thyroxine: Thyroid hormones, particularly thyroxine, are crucial for both physical growth and brain development during fetal life.

 

Option C. Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF): IGFs, particularly IGF-2 during fetal life (and IGF 1 in adult life), play a significant role in promoting cellular growth and development. IGFs are produced in response to fetal pituitary signals but are the main drivers of growth, not GH itself.

 

Educational Objective:


Growth hormone is not responsible for intrauterine growth due to the underdeveloped nature of its receptors in the fetus, making insulin, thyroxine, and IGFs the primary hormones for fetal growth.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, which are the two most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs. This resistance makes MDR-TB more difficult and longer to treat than drug-susceptible TB.

 

Isoniazid and rifampicin: These are the cornerstone drugs in the treatment of TB. MDR-TB's resistance to these drugs necessitates the use of second-line medications and a longer, more complex treatment regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and fluoroquinolone: While resistance to fluoroquinolones can occur, it characterizes pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) TB or extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB, not just MDR-TB.

 

Option B. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone resistance typically occurs in more advanced drug-resistant TB cases like pre-XDR and XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and kanamycin: This option refers to XDR-TB, which includes resistance to at least isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a second-line injectable drug such as kanamycin.

 

Note – Old definition of XDR - H and R resistance plus at least one fluoroquinolone resistance plus at least one second line injectable drug resistance like aminoglycosides (amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

choices.text: Amyloid light chain (AL)
Amyloid associated protein (AA)

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is more likely to develop in a patient undergoing long-term hemodialysis due to renal failure? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M)

 

Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis (HAA) is a condition that occurs in patients who have been undergoing long-term hemodialysis, typically for chronic renal failure. The culprit protein in this form of amyloidosis is β2-microglobulin (Aβ2M).

 

β2-microglobulin is a component of MHC class I molecules and is normally filtered out by the kidneys. In patients with renal failure, and especially those on long-term dialysis, β2-microglobulin accumulates because it is not efficiently removed by the dialysis membrane. Over time, this accumulation can lead to the deposition of amyloid fibrils composed of Aβ2M in various tissues, particularly around joints, leading to conditions like carpal tunnel syndrome and other forms of osteoarticular amyloidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amyloid light chain (AL): This type of amyloidosis is associated with plasma cell dyscrasias, such as multiple myeloma, where abnormal light chains are produced and deposit as amyloid.

 

Option B. Amyloid associated protein (AA): AA amyloidosis is secondary to chronic inflammatory conditions like tuberculosis, rheumatoid arthritis, or chronic infections, where Serum Amyloid A (SAA) is overproduced and deposits as amyloid.
