Option D. Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR): ATTR amyloidosis involves transthyretin, a protein produced in the liver, which can form amyloid deposits either due to genetic mutations (familial amyloid polyneuropathies) or in wild-type form, primarily affecting the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure may experience the development of amyloidosis due to the accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin.

 

Additional Information

 

A. Generalized/Systemic Amyloidosis

 

 

B. Localised Amyloidosis

 

 

C. Hereditary Amyloidosis

questions.text: What is the appropriate BIRADS category for a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 2

 

BIRADS 2 is used for benign findings. Given that the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a well-recognized benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most suitable category for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: BIRADS 1 is assigned to a category when there is no suspicion of malignancy, and BIRADS 2 is used when there is a benign finding. In this case, since the histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, which is a benign breast condition, BIRADS 2 is the most appropriate category.

 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 4: BIRADS 4 is used when there is a suspicious abnormality that may or may not be cancerous. Since the histology in this case indicates a fibroadenoma appearance, which is benign, BIRADS 4 would not be appropriate.

 

Option C. BIRADS 2, 3, or 4: BIRADS 3 is assigned when there is a probably benign finding that requires short-term follow-up. In this case, since the histology indicates a fibroadenoma appearance (a benign finding), BIRADS 3 and BIRADS 4 would not be applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a 23-year-old woman with a breast lump, no skin changes, and no indurations, whose histology shows a fibroadenoma appearance, the appropriate BIRADS category is BIRADS 2.

 

Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor that poses a low risk of malignancy. The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) categories are used to assess the likelihood of malignancy of breast lesions seen on mammograms, ultrasounds, or MRI. Grades 1 and 2 have a very low probability of being malignant, while grade 3 has a slightly higher probability of malignancy.

 

Grades 4 and 5 are considered suspicious and warrant further investigation as they have a higher probability of malignancy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease stage 3, and stable angina is scheduled for elective surgery. He experiences occasional chest pain that is relieved with rest and medications. His daily activities are somewhat limited by his health conditions, but he is not incapacitated. Which of the following ASA Physical Status Classifications corresponds to this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) ASA III

 

Explanation:


The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess a patient's preoperative health status and the associated risk during anesthesia. The system ranges from ASA I to ASA VI, each level describing the severity of the patient's systemic illness and its impact on their overall health and surgical risk.

 

ASA I: A normal healthy patient with no systemic disease and no limitations in their daily activities. Examples include a fit, non-smoking patient with no or minimal alcohol use.

 

ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease that is well controlled and does not significantly limit daily activities. Examples include controlled hypertension, mild diabetes without end-organ damage, mild obesity, or a history of smoking.

 

ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This category includes individuals whose health conditions are serious and impact their daily life but do not pose a constant threat to life. Examples include poorly controlled diabetes, stable angina, chronic kidney disease, or morbid obesity. The patient described here fits this category because his comorbidities are severe but managed well enough to avoid constant life-threatening status.

 

ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life. Conditions in this category include unstable angina, advanced heart failure, or end-stage renal disease requiring dialysis. Patients in this group are often severely limited in their daily activities due to their illness.

 

ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation. These patients have conditions such as a ruptured aortic aneurysm, massive trauma, or severe intracranial hemorrhage that necessitate surgery for any chance of survival.

 

ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) ASA I: This option is incorrect because it refers to healthy individuals without systemic disease, which does not match the patient's complex medical history.

 

Option B) ASA II: ASA II is reserved for patients with mild systemic disease that does not significantly impact daily activities or pose a substantial risk during surgery. The patient’s conditions, including poorly controlled diabetes and stable angina, are more severe than what is described by ASA II.

 

Option D) ASA IV: ASA IV describes patients with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, such as unstable angina or advanced heart failure. While the patient's conditions are serious, they are not immediately life-threatening, placing him in ASA III rather than IV.

 

Educational Objective:


ASA grade III is used to classify patients with severe systemic disease that significantly impacts daily functioning but is not incapacitating or an immediate threat to life.

 

Understanding the distinctions between ASA grades helps in assessing perioperative risk and planning for anesthesia management.

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center
Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is found to weigh 8kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) is provided below. Plot the growth chart for this child. What is the most appropriate advice based on the plotted graph? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

 

The WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) shows that the weight of 8 kg for a 16-month-old boy falls between -2 standard deviations (SD) and -3 SD, indicating moderate malnutrition. This suggests that the child is not receiving adequate nutrition and is at risk for growth and developmental delays.

 

In such cases, it is important to educate the mother on proper feeding practices to ensure the child receives a balanced diet with adequate nutrients. This can involve guidance on meal frequency, food variety, and portion sizes to improve the child's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No malnutrition - Assure the mother: This option is incorrect because the child’s weight for height falls between -2SD and -3SD on the growth chart, indicating moderate malnutrition rather than no malnutrition.

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition - home treatment: This option is incorrect as mild malnutrition is indicated when the weight-for-height is between -1SD and -2SD. The child’s weight falls between -2SD and -3SD, indicating moderate malnutrition.

 

Option C. Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center: This option is incorrect because severe malnutrition is diagnosed when the weight-for-height is less than -3SD. The child’s weight does not fall into this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moderate malnutrition in children is indicated by a weight-for-height between -2SD and -3SD on the WHO growth chart, necessitating education on proper feeding practices.

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

choices.text: Blast of air

questions.text: A man who was involved in a bomb blast at a railway station was brought to the hospital with multiple small puncture wounds to the left side of the chest and multiple small abrasions all over the body. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flying missiles

 

The case scenarios define multiple abrasions and puncture wounds suggestive of blast injuries due to flying missiles.

 

T.K. Marshall's (Marshall's triad of bomb injuries) :

 

    • Abrasions
    • Bruises/contusions
    • Puncture lacerations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blast of air: Primarily causes primary blast injuries, which affect air-filled organs and do not typically result in puncture wounds.

 

Option C. Explosion burns: Involve thermal injuries and burns rather than puncture wounds and abrasions.

 

Option D. Furniture abrasions: Would result from the victim being thrown into furniture or debris, causing blunt force injuries rather than puncture wounds.

 

Educational Objective

 

Classification of Blast injuries:

 

Injuries from explosions are traditionally classified into:

 

  1. Primary blast injuries: injuries due to solely to the blast wave
  2. Secondary blast or explosive injury: primarily ballistic trauma resulting from fragmentation wounds from the explosive device or the environment
  3. Tertiary blast or explosive injury: result of displacement of the victim or environmental structures, is largely blunt traumatic injuries
  4. Quaternary explosive injuries: burns, toxins, and radiologic contamination

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post coitus contraception means emergency contraception
  • Danazol is an androgen similar to testosterone and is used in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B CuT200: CUT200 is an intrauterine contraceptive device which can be used in emergency contraception (up to 120 h/ 5 days post coitus)

 

Option C. RU486: RU486 is Mifepristone. This is an anti-progesterone and can be used for emergency contraception)

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Combined high dose OCPs – used as Yuzpe’s regime, is a method of post-coital/ emergency contraception 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.text: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

 

Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.

 

Class I major histocompatibility complex are expressed on all nucleated cells

 

Class III major histocompatibility complex are some components of the complement system (C2 and C4) coded on HLA complex but are not associated with HLA expression and are not used in antigen identification.

 

 

MHC antigens present on the cell surface help the macrophage in its function of bacterial antigen recognition i.e., they help to identify self from foreign, and accordingly present the foreign antigen to T cells (CD4+ or CD8+) or to B cells.

 

MHC I are located on a portion of chromosome 6p of all nucleated cells of the body and platelets. These genes occupy four regions or loci—A, B, C and D, on the short (p) arm of chromosome 6 and exhibit marked variation in allelic genes at each locus. Therefore, the product of HLA antigens is highly polymorphic.

 

The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6.

 

Role of MHC/ HLA typing include:

 

  1. Organ Transplantation
  2. Regulation of immune system
  3. Association of diseases with HLA. An increasing number of diseases have been found to have association with some specific histocompatibility antigens. Ex:
  4. Inflammatory disorders e.g., ankylosing spondylitis
  5. Autoimmune disorders e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, insulin dependent diabetes mellitus.
  6. Inherited disorders of metabolism e.g., idiopathic haemochromatosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NK cells: While natural killer (NK) cells play a role in immune responses, they do not express MHC class II molecules.

 

Option B. All nucleated cells: This describes MHC Class I expression, not MHC Class II.

 

Option D. Platelets: Although platelets are derived from nucleated cells, they do not express MHC Class II molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC Class II molecules are primarily expressed on antigen presenting cells (B cells, dendritic cells, and mononuclear phagocytes), which are essential for antigen presentation to T-helper cells.

choices.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide
It should be taken empty stomach
It is given as a loading dose

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose
 

Voriconazole requires a loading dose to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the body. This is a crucial aspect of its administration, especially in acute settings where rapid antifungal activity is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with pyrazinamide: There is no significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole does interact with many other medications due to its effect on cytochrome P450 enzymes, but pyrazinamide is not one of the primary concerns.

 

Option B. It should be taken empty stomach: Voriconazole can be taken either with or without food, but it is generally recommended to take it one hour before or one hour after a meal to ensure optimal absorption. While this is important, it is not the most critical consideration compared to therapeutic drug monitoring.

 

Option D. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: While therapeutic drug monitoring can be important for voriconazole, especially in certain patient populations, it is not as universally mandated or emphasized as the initial loading dose regimen in standard treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

choices.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility
Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.text:
A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below.(INICET MAY 2023)

 

Initial lung volumes were: FEV1 - 0.9L, FVC - 1.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

After bronchodilation: FEV1 - 1.9L, FVC - 3.9L, FEV1/FVC - 0.4

 

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive disease with bronchodilator reversibility

 

The pulmonary function test results show a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, consistent with obstructive lung disease. Significant improvement in FEV1 post-bronchodilation indicates reversibility (FEV1 - anything >200ml is significant), suggesting conditions like asthma or COPD with reversible obstruction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Vascular disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Pulmonary function tests do not suggest vascular disease.


Option B. Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility: Restrictive diseases show reduced volumes but normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio.


Option C. Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility: Not applicable as the patient shows obstructive pattern with reversibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive lung diseases, such as asthma or COPD, may show bronchodilator reversibility.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: (AIIMS Nov 2019)

 

  1. More common in males than females.
  2. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  3. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur.
  4. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

 

Explanation:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Etiology:
    • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. 
    • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
    • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • Treatment:

 

 

  • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

questions.text: Which tendons are involved in the test shown below?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) APL and EPB

 

  • Finkelstein test has been shown which helps to diagnose de Quervain’s tenosynovitis (Inflammation of Abductor Pollicis Longus and Extensor Pollicis brevis).

 

DE QUERVAIN’S TENOSYNOVITIS

 

  • The abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons may become inflamed beneath the retinacular pulley at the radial styloid within the first extensor compartment.
  • Finkelstein’s test is pathognomonic.
  • The examiner places patients’ thumb across the palm in full flexion, and then holding the patient’s hand firmly, turns the wrist sharply into adduction.
  • In positive test, this is acutely painful; repeating the movement with the thumb left free is relatively painless.

 

 

  • Differential diagnosis includes scaphoid non-union, arthritis at the base of thumb and intersection syndrome.
  • Treatment includes NSAIDs with splint. If it fails, then steroid injection into tendon sheath and if not relieved then treatment consists of splitting the thickened tendon sheath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons are inflamed in the condition called De Quervain Tenosynovitis.
  • The diagnostic special test for the condition is called Finkelstein Test as shown in the image in the question.

questions.text: A patient with reduced hemoglobin and gum bleeding presented to you. He has thrombocytopenia (platelet count 25,000/µl) elevated PT, and aPTT. Which of the following can the probable cause of his finding? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AML t (15;17)

 

The clinical presentation of reduced hemoglobin, gum bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and elevated PT and aPTT is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is associated with the t(15;17) translocation, is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) that commonly presents with DIC.

 

Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL):

 

  • Genetics: APL is characterized by the t(15;17) translocation, which results in the PML-RARA fusion gene. This translocation disrupts the retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARA) gene, leading to a block in myeloid differentiation at the promyelocyte stage.
  • Clinical Features: Patients often present with symptoms of bleeding (e.g., gum bleeding, bruising) due to DIC, which is a common complication of APL.
  • Laboratory Findings: Thrombocytopenia, elevated PT, and aPTT are consistent with DIC. The peripheral smear may show promyelocytes with Auer rods.
  • Management: APL is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), which induces differentiation of the malignant promyelocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML t(8;21): Associated with AML with maturation, typically presenting with myeloblasts and not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option C. AML t(16;16): Associated with AML with abnormal eosinophils, also not commonly associated with DIC.

 

Option D. AML with NPM1: NPM1 mutations are common in AML but do not specifically correlate with DIC or the presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) associated with t(15;17) translocation commonly presents with DIC, characterized by thrombocytopenia and elevated coagulation times (PT and aPTT). DIC is due to release of procoagulant substances from the abnormal promyelocytes. Immediate identification and treatment with ATRA are crucial to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: In the context of the health belief model, a medical student is reviewing its different components. One of the boxes, labeled "C", is described as the individual's willingness to act on their beliefs regarding health threats and the benefits of taking preventive action. Which of the following best represents box C? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Health motivation

 

  • Box C stands for health motivation.
  • This represents the individual's readiness and willingness to engage in health-promoting behaviors.
  • This motivation influences how individuals perceive their susceptibility and severity of health issues, as well as the benefits and barriers to taking action.

 

 

The health belief model was proposed from the idea that a person's health behaviour changes in accordance with certain beliefs.

 

It can be categorized as follows:

 

  • Individual perceptions.
  • Variable factors that modify beliefs.
  • Action.

 

Individual perceptions:

 

Perceived susceptibility refers to a person's own beliefs about the probability of developing a disease. If the perceived susceptibility is high, an individual is more likely to engage in health-promoting behaviour to reduce the chances of contracting the illness.

 

Perceived severity is an individual's assessment of the severity of a particular health problem. If the disease is perceived to have a high severity, then the person is more likely to adopt a healthier lifestyle. Perceived threat comprises perceived susceptibility and severity. People with a higher perceived threat tend to take on health-promoting activities.

 

Action:

 

Perceived benefits refer to a person's subjective judgment on how a particular health habit is modifying his chances of developing a disease. If the person believes that a habit is likely to reduce his/her chances of susceptibility to a disease or lower the severity of a disease, he/she is more likely to follow that healthy habit.

 

Perceived barriers to action also influence if a person wants to follow healthy behaviour. The benefits of a particular health habit must overweigh the barriers that a person must overcome to continue following that behaviour.

 

Cues to action may be internal or external. Internal cues include pain and clinical symptoms. External cues include awareness through media, physicians, and friends.

 

The health belief system is thought to be useful in analyzing health behaviour patterns and formulating disease prevention plans based on these beliefs. All internal and external factors, including demographic and psychological characteristics, aim at health motivation to attain the action phase of a health belief system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perceived control: Perceived control refers to a person's internal belief in the control they would have over things that are part of the past or the future or over a process, behavior, and outcome. Perceived control can influence all of the categories of the health belief system.

 

Option B. Behavioral modification: Behavioral modification is part of the action after assessing all of the above-mentioned concepts.

 

Option D. Self-efficacy: Self-efficacy can be defined as a person's capacity in achieving his health goals. A person's confidence in his/her ability to overcome limitations to attain his/her health goals was found to be a major factor in determining the outcome of his behavioral changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the health belief model, health motivation (Box C) represents an individual's willingness to act on their health beliefs regarding susceptibility, severity, benefits, and barriers to take preventive health actions.
